cit1.CITATION: 1. cit17.CITATION: The definition of synthetic compounds is controversial (Gaeta 2010; Olsen 2017), with reference both to their scope as a class of complex formations and to the description of their internal structure.

cit18.CITATION: The definition of synthetic compounds is controversial (Gaeta 2010; Olsen 2017), with reference both to their scope as a class of complex formations and to the description of their internal structure.

cit19.CITATION: The synthetic compounds we are dealing with in this study belong to the type of complex nominal formations consisting of a nominal constituent derived from a verb and a constituent representing an argument of this verb (cf. Lieber 2016; Bauer et al. 2013), as in (1) book-reader.

cit20.CITATION: The synthetic compounds we are dealing with in this study belong to the type of complex nominal formations consisting of a nominal constituent derived from a verb and a constituent representing an argument of this verb (cf. Lieber 2016; Bauer et al. 2013), as in (1) book-reader.

cit21.CITATION: Whereas often deverbal derivation is equated to overt suffixation, we follow Lieber (2010) in including nominalizing verb conversion (or zero-suffixation in other traditions), as in (3) dog attack, haircut, bee sting.

cit22.CITATION: As to the prototypical three components of synthetic compounds (4) A+B+C of, e.g., tennis+play+er we study not only those where a compound A+B+C is not paralleled by a phrase A+B and a derived noun B+C, but also the so-called semi-synthetic compounds where both A+B and B+C coexist (cf. Werner 2017; Olsen 2017:19), as in (5) book-read+er, which coexists with read books and read+er.

cit23.CITATION: As to the prototypical three components of synthetic compounds (4) A+B+C of, e.g., tennis+play+er we study not only those where a compound A+B+C is not paralleled by a phrase A+B and a derived noun B+C, but also the so-called semi-synthetic compounds where both A+B and B+C coexist (cf. Werner 2017; Olsen 2017:19), as in (5) book-read+er, which coexists with read books and read+er.

cit24.CITATION: Or there is no suffix at all (or, in other traditions, there is a zero derivational suffix), as in Lithuanian, Greek, Russian, a pattern also of Proto-Indo-European origin (Fellner and Grestenberger 2016).

cit25.CITATION: This may be linked to the fact that Russian, Lithuanian and Greek have largely root-and stem-based morphologies, the other languages of our sample largely word-based morphologies (cf. Iordȃchioaia et al. 2017).

cit26.CITATION: Thus, for us, root compounding means having a root as base element of a compound (as in Iordȃchioaia et al. 2017) and is therefore not identical with the notion of root compounding in the sense of primary (i.e. non-synthetic) compounding.

cit27.SECTION: History of research on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit27.CITATION: First-language acquisition of synthetic compounds has been reported so far rather marginally together with acquisition of compounds in general (e.g. Stephany 1980; Dalalakis 1999; Xarčenko and Ozerova 1999; Rainer 2010:36-37; Argus and Kazakovskaya 2013; Stephany and Thomadaki 2016).

cit33.CITATION: In a more specific study, Clark et al. (1986; cf. Clark 1998:387-388) found that English synthetic compounds are acquired later than other productive, transparent and more simple compounds and that their constituents may be misordered in analogy to syntactic word-order (e.g. E. throwbutton vs. button-thrower).

cit46.CITATION: Our approach to the study of synthetic compounds is (as in Dressler et al. 2017) lexicalist and not syntactic (cf. Olsen 2017), i.e. we assume that compounding does not belong to syntax, but to word-formation, which has the lexical function of enriching the lexicon and to motivate complex words, including compounds in form and meaning (cf. Dressler 2007).

cit47.CITATION: Our approach to the study of synthetic compounds is (as in Dressler et al. 2017) lexicalist and not syntactic (cf. Dressler 2007).

cit48.CITATION: Our approach to the study of synthetic compounds is (as in Dressler et al. 2017) lexicalist and not syntactic (cf. Olsen 2017), i.e. we assume that compounding does not belong to syntax, but to word-formation, which has the lexical function of enriching the lexicon and to motivate complex words, including compounds in form and meaning (cf. Dressler 2007).

cit49.CITATION: In regard to acquisition our approach is constructivist (Bittner et al. 2003), insofar as we assume that children construct their grammar in response to their input (for our age-brackets mainly child-directed parental speech = CDS).

cit50.CITATION: It is compatible with constructional morphology (Booij 2010 ) and usage-based models (Bybee 2013) in assuming that acquisition starts with the selective taking over of constructions in the input without first decomposing them.

cit51.CITATION: It is compatible with constructional morphology (Booij 2010 ) and usage-based models (Bybee 2013) in assuming that acquisition starts with the selective taking over of constructions in the input without first decomposing them.

cit52.CITATION: Our approach is also compatible with preference theories (Dressler 1999; Bittner et al. 2003) in supposing (incl. the factors just mentioned) extralinguistic (especially cognitive) bases rather than universal grammatical bases for the preferences children demonstrate in the acquisition of compounding.

cit53.CITATION: Our approach is also compatible with preference theories (Dressler 1999; Bittner et al. 2003) in supposing (incl. the factors just mentioned) extralinguistic (especially cognitive) bases rather than universal grammatical bases for the preferences children demonstrate in the acquisition of compounding.

cit58.CITATION: But these tests would have to be administered to many more children than those of timeconsuming longitudinal studies, would be unsuitable for the study of compounding in the earliest phases of development, they would lack information about children's inputs (children do not have access to the target language directly but only via their input, which differs much from what we find in grammars, dictionaries and adult electronic corpora, cf. Ravid et al. 2008), they would be atomistic in focusing on one or very few phenomena, and they would just represent flashlights into one or very few moments of their development, i.e. they violate the requirement of path dependency of social sciences.

cit59.SECTION: Emergence and further development of synthetic compounds
cit59.CITATION: With the protomorphological phase, when children detect morphological decomposition and composition, compounds emerge simultaneously with inflection, diminutive and possessive formation (cf. Rus. Adj. pap+in ‘fatherly’ from papa ‘dad’), if compounding and these derivational processes are sufficiently rich and productive in the respective language in child-directed speech (Bittner et al. 2003; Stephany and Voeikova 2009; Savickienė and Dressler 2007; Tribushinina et al. 2015).

cit63.SECTION: Emergence and further development of synthetic compounds
cit63.CITATION: Otherwise derivational morphology tends to emerge later than compounding, because it is less descriptive and thus less morphosemantically transparent (cf. the last element of dish+washing+machine and of dish+wash+er) and because the elements of compounds have more autonomy than the affixed elements of derivations (Dressler 2005).

cit64.SECTION: Emergence and further development of synthetic compounds
cit64.CITATION: Of acquisition we can speak only, if there is some chance of decomposition, i.e. when lexical parts of synthetic compounds have emerged as autonomous words or parts of other compounds in the same position before, or simultaneously with, the emergence of the respective synthetic compounds (what we elaborated in terms of the miniparadigm criterion in Bittner et al. 2003; Savickienė and Dressler 2007).

cit66.SECTION: Emergence and further development of synthetic compounds
cit66.CITATION: One sign of productivity (corresponding to a common understanding of productivity in adult language, cf. Bauer 2001) are novel compounds created by children (cf. Dressler et al. 2017).

cit70.SECTION: Children's morphosemantic patterns of synthetic compounds
cit70.CITATION: Deverbal nominalizations, including synthetic compounds, include different semantic subtypes whose semantic interrelations have been widely discussed (cf. Alexiadou and Rathert 2010; Simone and Insacco 2017).

cit72.SECTION: Children's morphosemantic patterns of synthetic compounds
cit72.CITATION: The most prominent ones are agent nouns (often, e.g. by Clark and Hecht 1982, considered to be synchronically and diachronically primary, but see Meibauer 1999; Rainer 2010), instrument nouns, action nouns and result nouns.

cit74.SECTION: Children's morphosemantic patterns of synthetic compounds
cit74.CITATION: The most prominent ones are agent nouns (often, e.g. by Clark and Hecht 1982, considered to be synchronically and diachronically primary, but see Meibauer 1999; Rainer 2010), instrument nouns, action nouns and result nouns.

cit75.SECTION: Distribution of the above subtypes and their orders of emergence
cit75.CITATION: The near-total lack of deverbal local nouns fits to their relative rareness in the number of languages having them and in their small type and token frequency in languages which have them, as well as to their secondary status in diachronic development (Simone and Insacco 2017).

cit76.SECTION: Distribution of the above subtypes and their orders of emergence
cit76.CITATION: The preference of young children and, as a consequence, of caretakers for instrument nouns seems to reflect children's interest in instruments, which are more likely to be talked about than agents or action nouns in what Slobin (1985:1175) called "manipulative activity scenes" in early mother -child interaction.

cit77.SECTION: Distribution of the above subtypes and their orders of emergence
cit77.CITATION: Instrument and Agent nouns have been found to be acquired before action nouns (Ravid and Avidor 1998).

cit78.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit78.CITATION: In regard to research question 2 of the introduction (Sect. 1) we have found, even for semantic subtypes (Sects. 7 and 8), clear correspondences of type and token frequencies between the input and the output of children, in analogy to the acquisition of compounds in general (Dressler et al. 2017), only in German the rank frequency order is in two ways different in CS and CDS.

cit79.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit79.CITATION: This is also compatible with a model of complexity counting numbers of morphological and, indirectly, of phonological elements of a word or of rules applied in derivation (Schiff and Katan 2014).

cit80.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit80.CITATION: Finally, it should be noted that evidence for a building-block model is problematic for a radical interpretation of usage-based acquisition models which assume that morphologically complex words are acquired in total and decomposed very late (cf. Bybee 2013; Tomasello 2003).

cit81.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit81.CITATION: Finally, it should be noted that evidence for a building-block model is problematic for a radical interpretation of usage-based acquisition models which assume that morphologically complex words are acquired in total and decomposed very late (cf. Bybee 2013; Tomasello 2003).

cit82.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit82.CITATION: With respect to language typology (research question 3), the amount and importance of the rise of synthetic compounds does not clearly support Pye and Pfeiler's (2013) claim of the importance of language affiliation for similarities between languages in acquisition, This is indicated most clearly by the differences between Danish and German: In Danish, early CS there occurs only a single synthetic compound, although Danish has many synthetic compounds similarly to German.

cit83.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit83.CITATION: Thus, German goes here with English (Clark et al. 1986), whereas cognate Danish is very different.

cit84.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit84.CITATION: In terms of general language typology, this last observation might fit to a picture of morphologically rich agglutinating languages having less rich compounding than morphologically rich inflecting-fusional languages (in the sense of Skalička 1979).

cit85.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit85.CITATION: Also the typological opposition between largely word-based vs. largely root-and stem-based morphologies (which would mean largely word-based Estonian, Finnish, Saami, German vs. largely root/stem-based Greek, Lithuanian, Russian), as proposed by Iordȃchioaia et al. (2017:50) for English vs. Greek does not offer a convincing explanation for the differences in emergence of synthetic compounds, because the dates of emergence do not contrast along this contrast.

cit86.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit86.CITATION: Thus, analogically to what we have found for compounds in general (Dressler et al. 2017) vs. for inflection (Xanthos et al. 2011), differences between language types appear to have an impact on the acquisition of inflection but not of compounding, because the concepts of these language types have been heavily based on inflection.

cit87.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit87.CITATION: Thus, analogically to what we have found for compounds in general (Dressler et al. 2017) vs. for inflection (Xanthos et al. 2011), differences between language types appear to have an impact on the acquisition of inflection but not of compounding, because the concepts of these language types have been heavily based on inflection.

cit88.SECTION: Conclusions on the acquisition of synthetic compounds
cit88.CITATION: More precisely though, it is not richness and productivity as being characteristic of the target language as a whole but within the genres that are likely to occur in CDS: this is very clearly the case in Greek, where rich and productive compounding is typically found in high-register genres of written language e.g. in formal, scientific, technical texts (as forcefully argued by Stephany and Thomadaki 2016).

cit92.CITATION: Productivity of morphological patterns in adult language is characterized by their regular appearance in neologisms, especially when formed from recent loan-words (Dressler 2007).

Bittner et al. 2003 viii-ix, xviii) and for the inclusion of synthetic compounds into a compounding component of morphology, because these Viennese children constructed an identical blind alley for both synthetic and non-synthetic compounds.

cit102.SECTION: Discussion of evidence for theoretical issues of synthetic compounds
cit102.CITATION: Therefore, the suggestion of Meibauer and Vogel (2017:13, in the preface of their special issue) that for synthetic compounds a "ternary (holistic) analysis is called for" may be true for early phases of the acquisition of synthetic compounds: first, synthetic compounds would be learned as holistic units, as also implicitly assumed in any usage-based approach; in a second phase, decomposition would start in a ternary way, thus excluding a recency effect of truncation of the first lexical element (see above).

cit103.SECTION: Discussion of evidence for theoretical issues of synthetic compounds
cit103.CITATION: What the slower development of synthetic compounds in comparison with other types of endocentric compounds (Dressler et al. 2017 ) and, within derivational morphology, at least in comparison with diminutive formations, agent and instrument nouns, and particle verbs, shows, is that synthetic compounds are more complex morphological patterns than those of other word-formation patterns (not to speak of the core of inflectional morphology).

cit104.SECTION: Discussion of evidence for theoretical issues of synthetic compounds
cit104.CITATION: One reason why synthetic compounds are more complex than comparable three-constituent compounds and derivations, is that constructions can be called more complex if more rules are involved (Van den Bos and Poletiek 2008).
